awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Impact of COVID-19 Disruptions on Education and Child Well-being
awd_abstract_narration:
COVID-19 disrupted in-person education for many schools for an entire academic year. In addition, children missed opportunities to participate in non-traditional education initiatives outside of the classroom, an impact amplified for vulnerable students and families. This project evaluates school gardens pre- and post-COVID-19 as sites for supporting resilience of low-income minority communities at under-resourced schools. Previous research by the investigators has shown that school gardens produce positive social and academic outcomes. This project uses a quasi-experimental research design using to evaluate the emotional, behavioral, cognitive, and interpersonal well-being of children aged seven to fourteen. Resilience measures include assessing a child’s sense of purpose, authenticity, equanimity, self-reliance, and perseverance. These data are compared to resilience measures acquired from school garden programs that were in place for several years prior to pre-COVID-19. This project advances existing socio-spatial theory in geographical science by highlighting the positive, mediating effects of nature in the relationship between society and space for children.

A vast research literature spanning the social sciences illustrates that resilience is foundational to academic success and a productive and satisfying life. Resilience is often eroded by poverty through the shame, confusion, and anger that drive acting-out behaviors that can lead to troubled children and compromised adult lives. School gardens offer environments that support resilience in a child’s ability to recognize their unique capacity and respond to life events positively. This study contributes new data on the impact that environmental disruptions in general have on child well-being.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We studied four Title I schools in the Tucson Unified School District to determine what impacts school gardens might have in building resilience among students from under-resourced households. Two of the schools had gardens that had been operational for over a decade and teachers trained in garden-based learning. The other two schools did not have gardens or teachers familiar with learning through gardens. A total of seven different fourth grade classes were included in the study. Our research was particularly focused on investigating whether gardens make a difference to children’s resilience by strengthening social and emotional skills following the highly stressful period of the COVID-19 quarantine when early research was already showing increased trauma among children with adverse childhood experiences.

 Four researchers observed approximately 120 fourth grade students in their classrooms, school gardens and in special activities. Observations occurred for 1 hour every day for all seven classes during every week school was in session in the 2021-2022 school year. We scheduled observations for different time slots each week to cover both morning and afternoon activities as well as the manifestations of children’s social and emotional competencies throughout the school day. Observation commenced the second week in October (2021) and ended the third week in May (2022).

 

We found that students who used gardens for learning enjoyed many more opportunities to practice and express:

• independence, competence, and relatedness

• positive emotions such as joy, satisfaction, and excitement

• initiative and industry

• real-world problem solving skills

Our research confirmed as well as extended the existing literature on school gardens first by coroborratinging how school gardens foster children’s natural sense of curiosity and that school gardens provide a unique space to cultivate social and emotional growth in a real-world setting. And second, because our research was situated in the period immediately following the end of the COVID-19 period, we gained new insights into the restorative power of school gardens. Garden-based learning offered amelioration to some of the negative impacts on social and emotional development that traumatized students exhibited exhibitted upon their immediate return to the classroom following the quarantine.

 


Last Modified: 01/22/2024
Modified by: Sallie A Marston
